div.p: This sub-element can be found in BIOGRAPHY CULTURALFORMATION . It is specifically grouped with the larger RELIGION sub-element. Used to capture the names of religious beliefs and denominations associated with a person's life, we are defining DENOMINATION very broadly to include a wide range of categories from Christian to atheist to Buddhist to Seekers to Clapham Sect. While we recognize that many of the denominations listed below are conceptually different (for example, Buddhism is on a different hierarchical, conceptual level from Calvinist), for the purposes of this Project we are overlooking these distinctions.

This element goes around the name of the denomination. To the best of your ability, select a name from the list of controlled vocabulary below and phrase your sentence to include the proper name (i.e. use She was a Quaker rather than Quakerism was her religion). The tag has optional attributes of CURRENTALTERNATIVETERM, SELF-DEFINED, and REG, which allows you to express the denomination in a standard form if you have been unable to do so in your prose.

div.codeblock: PJB was a Scottish writer and her later work reveals a Unitarian bent.
UT converted fromAnglicanism to Catholicism.

div.p: To the best of your ability, use the list of controlled vocabulary for denominations below. If your denomination is not included in this list, use the name best suited to your writer.

Because we use the principle of following the author's own terminology, it is not always possible to achieve a standard naming of the same denomination. For example, Anglicanism may also appear under the names Church of England or Church of Ireland. When you can, use the REG attribute to standardize these names to Anglican. And avoid using lengthy descriptive phrases to describe the denomination; use instead a noun descriptor. N.b. entities like the Anglican Church, Roman Cathollic Church, Islam, need to be tagged with an ORGNAME as well as DENOMINATION, so that searches will find writers belonging to them, along with other data about them. For the purposes of this project, we consider Atheism and agnosticism as denominations. Obviously, calling atheism a religious denomination is an oxymoron but conceptually, we have linked these together.
Question: What should I do if I don't know the specific religion of my writer and all I know is that she was Christian?

Answer: When nothing more specific is known, include Christian as a denomination (ORGNAME Christianity). But bear in mind that baptism or marriage in a parish church in England is presumptive evidence of at least tenuous Anglicanism.
Question: Is Jewish a DENOMINATION? RACE? ETHNICITY?
Answer: Can be tagged as any of these, depending on data. If DENOMINATION, the REG form is Judaism.
